title: Spinning a Wheel for a Discount: Determining Shape
question_text:
A car dealership is having a big promotion where customers who purchase a car can spin a spinner to determine how much of a discount they will get off the purchase price. Discounts range from $\$500$ to $\$2500$.
The spinner is shown below and all wedges on the spinner are equal in area.

If a boxplot was created to display the distribution of discount amounts, what would the boxplot reveal about the shape of the distribution?

choices.text: The distribution would be approximately normal.
The distribution would be skewed left.
The distribution would be skewed right.
Since the spinner is really just a pie chart in disguise, the variable of interest is categorical. Therefore, a boxplot cannot be used to display the distribution of discounts.

Since the boxplot is more stretched out on the right, the distribution is skewed right.

Explanation of Distractors

Since the distribution is skewed right, this makes Choices 'A', 'B', and 'D' incorrect since these all reference a different type of shape.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. The variable of interest is the amount of the discount, which is a quantitative variable. The spinner is simply a way to determine how much of a discount the customer will receive. And while it is true that the spinner might really just be a pie chart in disguise, this does not change the fact that the variable of interest is quantitative. Therefore, a boxplot is an appropriate type of graphical display.
